Welcome to cgn’s documentation!¶

class CGN¶

Bases: object

Constrained Gauss-Newton solver for nonlinear least-squares problems with linear constraints.

Variables

  • options – Allows to modify the options for the solver. See cgn.cnls_solve.solveroptions.Solveroptions for the modifiable options.

  • linesearch – Allows to set options for the linesearch method. See cgn.cnls_solve.linesearch_options.LinesearchOptions for the modifiable options.

solve(problem, starting_values)¶

Computes the solution of the constrained nonlinear least-squares problem using the constrained Gauss-Newton method.

Parameters

  • problem (cgn.problem.problem.Problem) – The optimization problem to solve.

  • starting_values (List[numpy.ndarray]) – The starting values for the optimization. The length of the list must be equal to Problem.nparams.

Returns

The solution to the optimization problem.

Return type

cgn.problem.problem_solution.ProblemSolution

class DiagonalOperator(dim, s)¶

Bases: cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator

Tool to form diagonal regularization operators of the form \(R = \mathrm{diag}(s_1, \ldots, s_n)\).

Parameters

s (Union[float, numpy.ndarray]) – All entries must me larger than 0. If s is a float, the resulting diagonal operator will be \(R = \mathrm{diag}(s, \ldots, s)\). If s is a vector, the resulting diagonal operator will be \(R = \mathrm{diag}(s_1, \ldots, s_n)\).

class IdentityOperator(dim)¶

Bases: cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator

class MultipliedOperator(regop, q)¶

Bases: cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator

Implements a regularization operator that is created by right-multiplying a given regularization operator with a matrix. That is, given a regularization operator :math`R` and a matrix \(Q\), the new regularization operator corresponds to \(R Q\).

Parameters

  • regop (cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator) – The regularization operator \(R\).

  • q (numpy.ndarray) – The matrix \(Q\) by which the regularization operator is multiplied. It must have shape (n,m), where n = regop.dim.

class Problem(dims, fun, jac, q=None, scale=1.0)¶

Bases: object

Class for formulating regularized nonlinear least-squares problems with linear constraints:

\[\begin{split}\min_{x_1,...,x_p} \quad & ||Q F(x_1,...,x_p)||_2^2 + \beta_1 * ||R_1(x_1 - m_1)||_2^2 + \ldots + \beta_2 * ||R_p(x_p - m_p)||_2^2 \\ s.t. \quad & Ax = b, \quad Cx \geq d, \quad x \geq l.\end{split}\]
Parameters

  • dims (List[int]) – The dimensions of the parameters.

  • fun (callable) – A function accepting argument of the format specified by dims. That is, it should accept len(dims) arguments, and the i-th argument must be a numpy array with shape (dims[i],). The output should be a numpy array of shape (m,).

  • jac (callable) – The Jacobian corresponding to fun. It should accept the same argument as fun, and the output should be a numpy array with shape (m, n), where n = sum(dims).

  • q (Union[numpy.ndarray, cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator]) – The regularization of the misfit term. Typcially, this will be a square root of the noise precision matrix. Can either be a numpy array or a RegularizationOperator.

  • scale (float) – The scale of the cost function. This only matters for the optimization. If provided, the cost function is divided by the scale. A good default choice for this parameter is m.

add_equality_constraint(a, b, i=None)¶

Adds an equality constraint of the form \(A x = b\).

Parameters

  • a (numpy.ndarray) – Of shape (c,n), where n must equal the dimension of the desired parameter.

  • b (numpy.ndarray) – Of shape (c,).

  • i (Optional[int]) – The number of the parameter for which the constraint is set. For example, if paramno=2, then the constraint will be \(A x_2 = b\). If paramno is not specified, a global constraint of the form \(A x = b\) is set, where x is the concatenated parameter vector.

add_inequality_constraint(c, d, i=None)¶

Adds an inequality constraint of the form \(Cx \geq d\).

Parameters

  • c (Union[int, float, complex, str, bytes, numpy.generic, Sequence[Union[int, float, complex, str, bytes, numpy.generic]], Sequence[Sequence[Any]], numpy.typing._array_like._SupportsArray]) – Of shape (c,n), where n must equal the dimension of the desired parameter.

  • d (Union[int, float, complex, str, bytes, numpy.generic, Sequence[Union[int, float, complex, str, bytes, numpy.generic]], Sequence[Sequence[Any]], numpy.typing._array_like._SupportsArray]) – Of shape (c,).

  • i (Optional[int]) – The number of the parameter for which the constraint is set. For example, if paramno=2, then the constraint will be \(C x_2 \geq d\). If paramno is not specified, a global constraint of the form \(C x \geq d\) is set, where x is the concatenated parameter vector.

costfun(*args)¶

Returns the cost function.

\[\phi(x_1,\ldots, x_p) = \frac{1}{2} \left( ||Q F(x_1,...,x_p)||_2^2 + \beta_1 ||R_1(x_1 - m_1)||_2^2 + \ldots + \beta_p ||R_p(x_p - m_p)||_2^2 \right).\]
Parameters

args – The number of args should be equal to nparams.

Returns

Value of the cost function at given parameters.

Return type

float

costgrad(*args)¶

Returns the gradient of the cost function:

\[\nabla \phi(x_1,\ldots,x_p) = (QF'(x_1,\ldots,x_p))^\top Q F(x_1,\ldots,x_p) + \beta_1 R_1^\top R_1 (x_1 - m_1) + \ldots + \beta_p R_p^\top R_p (x_p - m_p).\]
Parameters

args – The number of args should be equal to nparams.

Returns

\(\nabla \phi\), of shape (n,).

Return type

numpy.ndarray

property equality_constraint: cgn.problem.linear_constraint.LinearConstraint¶
Returns

The equality constraint as LinearConstraint object.

property inequality_constraints: cgn.problem.linear_constraint.LinearConstraint¶
Returns

The inequality constraint as LinearConstraint object.

property lower_bound¶
Returns

The current lower bound l, where \(x \geq l\). If a component is not lower bounded, the corresponding value will be -np.inf.

property nparams: int¶
Returns

The number of parameters on which the problem depends.

set_lower_bound(lb, i=None)¶

Adds a lower bound constraint of the form \(x_i \geq l\).

Parameters

  • lb (numpy.ndarray) – The lower bound. Must be of shape (n,), where n is the dimension of the corresponding parameter.

  • i (Optional[int]) – The number of the parameter for which the lower bound is set.

set_regularization(paramno, m=None, beta=1.0, r=None)¶

Specify a regularization term for the desired parameter. The regularization term will be of the form \(\beta * ||R (x - m)||_2^2\).

Parameters

  • paramno (int) – Number of the parameter for which you want to specify a regularization term.

  • m (Optional[numpy.ndarray]) – Of shape (n,). If not provided, defaults to zero.

  • beta (float) – The regularization parameter. Defaults to 1. You can turn off regularization by setting beta = 0.

  • r (Optional[Union[cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator, numpy.ndarray]]) – The regularization operator for the parameter. Defaults to the identity.

Raises

ValueError – If the input is inconsistent.

class ProblemSolution(minimizer, precision, cost, success, niter)¶

Bases: object

Container for the solution of an optimization problem defined as instance of cgn.Problem.

Variables

  • minimizer – The minimizer of the optimization problem, given as a list [x0, x1, …].

  • precision – The posterior precision matrix. Of shape (n,n), where n is the overall parameter dimension.

  • cost – The minimum of the cost function.

  • success – True, if the iteration converged successfully. False, if the iteration stopped for other reasons.

  • niter – The number of iterations.

Parameters

  • minimizer (List[numpy.ndarray]) –

  • precision (numpy.ndarray) –

  • cost (float) –

  • success (bool) –

  • niter (int) –

Return type

None

class RegularizationOperator(mat)¶

Bases: object

Abstract base class for regularization operators. Each child of RegularizationOperator must implement the methods fwd and adj, which give the forward and the adjoint action of the regularization operator.

Parameters

mat (numpy.ndarray) –

adj(w)¶

Evaluates the adjoint action of the regularization operator. :param w: Of shape (r, m), where r = rdim. :return: Of shape (n, m), where n = dim.

Parameters

w (numpy.ndarray) –

property dim: int¶

The dimension of the domain of the regularization operator.

fwd(v)¶

Evaluates the forward action of the regularization operator. :param v: :param v: Of shape (n,m), where n = dim. :return: Of shape (r,m), where r = rdim.

Parameters

v (numpy.ndarray) –

Return type

numpy.ndarray

property mat: numpy.ndarray¶

The matrix representation of the regularization operator. A matrix of shape (r,n), where n= dim and r= rdim.

property rdim: int¶

The dimension of the codomain of the regularization operator.

class Solveroptions¶

Bases: object

The options for the constrained Gauss-Newton method.

Variables

  • maxiter – The maximum number of iterations. Defaults to 100.

  • tol – The tolerance. The solver stops once the difference between the current (c0) and the last (c1) value of the scaled costfunction is less or equal to tol * scale, where scale = max(abs(c0), abs(c1), 1). Defaults to 1e-10.

  • timeout – Gives the number of minutes after which the solver automatically terminates due to timeout. Default timeout is 60 minutes.

  • logfile – Specifies the name of the logfile for the solver output.

  • ctol – The tolerance for the constraint violation. The solver will only try to satisfy the constraint up to a tolerance specified by ctol. The default value is 1e-15.

set_verbosity(lvl)¶

Controls the amount of information displayed during and after the iteration.

Parameters

lvl (int) –

The verbosity level. There are currently 2 levels of verbosity:

  • 0: no output

  • 1: output to logfile (specified by logfile.)

  • 2: output to console at running time

  • 3: output both to console and logfile

make_block_operator(operator_list)¶

Given a list of regularization operators, creates a block operator as a direct sum. :param operator_list: :return: The resulting operator might either be a BlockOperator', or a :py:class:`NullOperator if all operators in the list are of instances of NullOperator.

Parameters

operator_list (List) –

Return type

cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator

scale_operator(regop, alpha)¶

Scales a regularization operator: Given a regularization operator \(P\) and a constant \(lpha\), the new operator is \(\sqrt(\alpha) P\). :param regop: :param alpha: :returns: If alpha is close to 0, then the returned operator is a NullOperator. Otherwise, it is a ScaledOperator.

Parameters

  • regop (cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator) –

  • alpha (float) –

Return type

cgn.regop.regularization_operator.RegularizationOperator
